So in rabbinic literature. This is an unusual transliteration, particularly the use of the ע, see under Aquila (5) (L/M) in vol. 1, p. 327. Yet, the Bible translator, who is mentioned frequently in the works of many Church fathers, appears as “Aquila,” e.g. in the ancient translation to Latin of Irenaeus of Lyon, Adversus Haereses 3:24.
So in Eusebius, see above, n. 2.

In the Yerushalmi Aquila the proselyte is mentioned 9 times (yDemai 6, 25d; yShab 6, 8b; yYoma 3:8, 41a; ySuk 3:8, 53d; yMeg 1, 71c; 2:1, 73b; yHag 2:1, 77a; yMQ 3:7, 83b; yQid 1:1, 59a). In 7 instances (excluding yDemai 6, 25d and yHag 2:1, 77a) the text deals with the translation of the Torah. The case of yDemai 6, 25d, is different, however, since it is parallel to a tradition from the Tosefta (tDemai6:13) where the proselyte involved is called אונקלוס. This proselyte is mentioned often in the Tosefta (tShab 7:18; tHag 3:3; tKel BB2:4; tMiq 6:3) but never in association with the Torah translation. The Tosefta, further, knows of no עקילס. In the Bavli only the name אונקלוס is recorded and he is associated with the translation of the Torah, as well as appearing in a parallel tradition to that of the Tosefta (bAZ 11a=tShab7:18). The two seem to have been confused as time went by, but it is doubtful whether the two were indeed the same person.
In Greek – Ποντικός.

This inscription is strikingly similar to CIJ 774, also from Apamea. The name of the wife is the same. The formulation of the epitaph is the same and it ends with a warning. However, while in CIJ 774 it ends with the mention of “the Jews” ([τ]ῶν Εἰυοδέων), here it ends with a fine to be paid to the treasury (ταμεῖον). The similarity may suggest a communal affinity, but not necessarily Jewishness.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

This inscription is strikingly similar to CIJ 774, also from Apamea. The name of the wife is the same. The formulation of the epitaph is the same and it ends with a warning. However, while in CIJ 774 it ends with the mention of “the Jews [τ]ῶν Εἰυοδέων,” here it ends with a fine to be paid to the treasury (ταμεῖον). The similarity may suggest a communal affinity, but not necessarily Jewishness.

A certain Marcus is mentioned by Josephus (AJ19:276) as being the nephew of Philo the philosopher and of having married Berenice, the daughter of King Agrippa (Berenice [2] [G/F] in vol. 1, p. 315). A. Fuks, “Markus Julius Alexander,” Zion 13 (1944) 10-7 (Hebrew), identified him with the Marcus Julius Alexander mentioned on these ostraca, who is a perfect contemporary (and whose brother was called Tiberius Julius Alexander), see also Ilan, Integrating Women, 219. However, if he is not identified with him, then he need not be Jewish.

If the former is correct, then he is of Roman provenance; if the latter then he is of the south (of Palestine). I lean toward the former because of his Latin name. In either case, his presence is the lection difficilior, because he is transmitting this tradition in the name of Judah bar Simon (see vol. 2), and in the parallels to this midrash in Tanhuma re’e 17, and Tanhuma Buber, re’e 18, he is not mentioned at all.

He is to be identified with Quintus Caecilius Niger mentioned in Cicero’s In Caecilium oratio quae divination dicitur and thus, as Cicero puts it “provincia … quaestorum” (1.2). Plutarch claims he was a freedman (ἀπελευθρικός).
In Plutarch, Vita Ciceronis 7:6 this person is accused of Jewish sympathies, see Introduction 6.1.6.2, but Cicero himself, who preserves his complete name, makes no such claims.

The mention in CPJ378 of a certain slave-owner, with the biblical name Sarah, as in earlier Edfu ostraca (see Sarah [4-5] [B/F]). However, the name Sarah here is reconstructed (Σάρ[ρας]) and even if correct, there are problems with the Jewishness of the name Sarah, see Introduction 6.6.4.1. And see also CPJ 2, p. 118.

The editors thought the inscription Jewish because it mentions Τραιανησίων and it was assumed on comparison with the title “Augustinians” found in Jewish inscriptions, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.1, that this was a Jewish community in Porto, which received its civic privileges from the emperor Trajan, but there is no other evidence for this premise. Also, the inscription is dedicated to θεοῦ μεγάλου Διωνύσου (the Great God Dionysus), see Introduction 6.10.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

The inscription comes from Aphrodisias, where Jews are attested (see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1), and mentions [θ]εῷ̔ψίστῳ (for the Almighty God), but this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.10.1.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
Described as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3.
His father is described as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
Described as [̓Ι]ουδέου (=Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3.

Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.

The inscription is dated.
In Greek – βουλ(ευτής).
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.

Jewishness was (not emphatically) suggested by the editor, based on the remarkable similarity of the inscription to IJO1, Arch 70-71, which also records the murder of children and requests revenge from God (there described as Θεὸν τὸν ̔́Υψιστουν τὸν Κύριου τῶν πνευμάτων καὶ πάσης σαρκὸς – God most high, Lord of the spirits and all flesh [Num 16:22]; here described as Κύρει Παντοκράτωρ – Lord the All mighty). On the similarity and non-Jewishness of Θεὸν τὸν ̔́Υψιστουνand Κύρει Παντοκράτωρ see Introduction 6.10.1.1. The main reason why this may be considered other than Jewish is the definitive date of this inscription 237/8 CE (just after the onset of Christianity), whereas the Delos inscriptions are dated on epigraphical grounds to the 2nd-1st centuries BCE.
The inscription is dated.
For the double consonant see Introduction 2.4.3.
In Latin – vicxit annis LXXXV.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Described by Josephus in AJ 20:100 as τοῖς γὰρ πατρίοις ο̓κ ἐμεμεινεν οὑτος ἔθεσιν ([he] did not stand by the practices of his people).
See CPJ 2, pp. 188-90.
On the transliteration of i with ε see Introduction 2.4.2.2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.

He was an imperial freedman and set up an inscription for Claudia Aster, see under Claudia (1) (L/F) in vol. 1, p. 342. She was Jewish. Whether he also was Jewish is unclear, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

Jewishness suggested based on wife’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.4. The fact that it does not state that the deceased is Jewish makes it more suspect in light of other sarcophagi from Hierapolis, see Introduction 6.1.1.3. IJO 2 did not include it in its corpus, see p. 399, n. 161.

Jewishness suggested by Feissel, REG 113 (2000) 598, based on curse formula (καταθῆται ἔσται α̓τῷ πρὸς το͂ν Θεόν – he will be answerable to God), but see Introduction 6.10.1.3.IJO 2 mentions this inscription but does not explain why it was not included in its corpus, see p. 68, n. 17.

The chapter begins with the words Μετὰ ταῦτα … ἤλθεν εἰς Κόρινθον (after this … [Paul] came to Corinth). This is where he met Titius.

Described in the text as σεβομένου τὸν θεόν (fearer of God). Whether this is just an indication of his Jewish piety or a technical term for his religious status, see Introduction 6.1.6.1, is not quite clear. He is also described as living next to the synagogue, but see Introduction 6.4.1.1.3.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.1, p. 51.
This is the standad abbreviation of this name,see Introduction 2.4.1. Reading according to Strubbe, “Curses,” 120. CIJ reads this as an abbreviation of T(iberius), but see under Tiberius (L/M), n. 7.

Jewishness suggested by IJO 2, 172, based on the mention of the curses that are written down (ὅσε ἀνγεγραμμέναι), which he identifies based on CIJ 760, as the curses from Deuteronomy, see, Introduction 6.9, but this is mere conjecture.
The inscription is dated.
For the double consonant see Introduction 2.4.3.

This is a Jewish politeuma inscription, see Introduction 6.4.2.2. It is set up in his honor. In favor of him being Jewish rather than pagan is another politeuma inscription from Cyrene (CJZC 70), where a man is in the same position is honored as a donor to the synagogue.
The inscription is dated.

The document is in Greek but this person’s name is recorded both in Greek and in Latin. This is the Greek.

The document is in Greek but this person’s name is recorded both in Greek and in Latin. This is the Latin. Although in Latin, the declension is Greek, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1. The form intended in Latin may be Orbanus, also a Latin cognomen, see RNGCL, 372.
This amulet mentions the Jewish God by name (Ιαω), but see Introduction 6.10.1.6. Further on the Jewishness of this amulet see Alexander, “Jewish Elements,” 1074-5.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

div.note: This is a Latin variation on the original name influenced by the feminine form (Agrippa-Agrippina-Agrippinus; RNGCL, 10, 290). On this phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.3, pp. 15-6.

Latin gentilium and cognomen, RNGCL, 16, 293. There is a similarity between this name and the transliteration of the biblical-Semitic name חנניה/חנינא into Greek and Latin. This has led to the identification of several persons bearing perfectly good Latin names as Jews. In this corpus, unless other, supporting evidence is presented, these identifications are rejected.
Latin gentilium, RNGCL, 16. On the “Jewishness” of this name see also above, under Annianus, n. 1.
Latin gentilium and cognomen, see RNGCL, 20, 294.

Latin gentilium and cognomen, RNGCL, 99, 347. Further on this name see vol. 1, p. 333. Many scholars think this is a typical Jewish name, e.g. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 143, but this cannot be a criterion for identifying Jewishness, see Introduction 1.2.4.
Latin gentilium, RNGCL, 105. Further on this name see vol. 1, pp. 333-4.
